chapters.title: Definition
chapters.text: Indexing is where you create a portfolio that focuses mainly on tracking of the performance of a market’s index. The most common index that is tracked is the S&P Index 500. Indexing can also refer to using metrics to measure the performance of economic activity.

chapters.title: Relevance
chapters.text: The method of indexing is most useful when an investor is interested in tracking data from a market index to follow its success and mimic their portfolio to also achieve that success. People can also calculate purchasing power of the US dollar or rate of inflation using the CPI or the Consumer Price Index.

chapters.title: Example
chapters.text: Adam is deciding to look into mutual funds and wants the most security with low risks. He decides that he likes the way that the S&P Index 500 is performing. He uses the Consumer Price Index to calculate the rate of inflation before getting into indexing the S&P Index 500. He also uses the CPI to adjust his interest rates for these investments and realizes the numbers work well with his plan and he decides he wants to mimic the performance of the market for the most success in his goals.
